seg.line: 夫晉國將守唐叔之所受法度，

tls:text.tls:srcline: 夫晉國將守唐叔之所受法度，
tls:text.tls:line: Tsin ought to keep the laws and rules which T'agn-shu received

sense.def: laws and regulations

tls:text.tls:srcline: 夫晉國將守唐叔之所受法度，
tls:text.tls:line: Tsin ought to keep the laws and rules which T'agn-shu received

sense.def: laws and regulations

tls:text.tls:line: to form the laws of the State.

sense.def: law of the land

tls:text.tls:line: And thrown into confusion his rules and laws:-

sense.def: laws and rules

tls:text.tls:line: They insolently cast aside all penal laws,

sense.def: criminal law

tls:text.tls:line: but the chief of the Wei clan,

sense.def: (presumably) only N is a case in point, only N is like this

tls:text.tls:line: There is no uncertainty in the ways of Heaven;

sense.def: doubt (ZUO)

tls:text.tls:line: "Formerly

sense.def: in bygone days

tls:text.tls:line: In the past I said to you,

sense.def: in bygone days

tls:text.tls:line: If we are really guilty,

sense.def: if

tls:text.tls:line: If the expedition is not successful,

sense.def: if

tls:text.tls:line: If Chǔ has no bad feelings towards us

sense.def: if

tls:text.tls:line: To do it once was more than enough;

sense.def: if
show parental love; show care
codified law text written on bamboo

Bào Wénzĭ 鮑文子 (fl. 528-501) appears to have been a descendant of >Bao Shuya 鮑叔牙 and is on record as a dignitary qualified to remonstrate on matters of state in the state of Qi. [ZUO Zhao 14 and 25, Ding 9; SY 17.28]
Cài Mù Hóu 蔡穆侯 (r. 674 - 646) is mentioned in ZUO Xi 6.4 for a diplomatic visit to the state of Chu.

Cáo Jī 曹羈 (fl. 670) was a military dignitary from the state of Cao 曹 mentioned in CQ Zhuang 24. Having remonstrated unsuccessfully with his ruler three times, when his state of Cao was being attacked by a barbarian tribe, Cai Ji went into exile in the state of Chen 陳. This episode is commented upon in GONGYANG Zhuang 24.

Duke Ling of Chen Chén Líng Gōng 陳靈公 (r. 613 – 599) is on historical record as having entered a contract with the regional lords in 608 [ZUO Xuan 1.8]. Otherwise, he became most famous for rumours of a lurid affair with a lady >Xia Ji 夏姬, wife of a dignitary in Chen 陳. He and his friends >Yi Xingfu 儀行父 and >Gongsun Ning 公孫寧 were all said to have been found sporting parts of the lady’s garments in court. Duke Ling executed many of those who remonstrated against his excesses. In 599, lady Xia Ji’s son Cheng Shu 徵舒 is said to have killed Duke Ling when he was teased for his resemblance to the Duke. The whole episode is dramatised in SJ 36.1579. [ZUO Xuan 9.6; HNZ 18.6a; SY 1.4; XINXU 1.19, ed. Shi Guangying 2001 p. 148, ed. Li Huanian p. 34]

Chŭ Shī 褚師 (fl. 480-470), also known as Shēngzĭ 聲子, was active in Wey 衛 under >Duke Chu of Wey 衛出公 (r. 492 – 481, and c. 477 - c. 456). In 479 he had to flee to his family home in Song 宋 after attempting an unsuccessful court intrigue. [ZUO Ai 16] In 470, having been humiliated by his ruler, he joined a revolt by dignitaries in Wey. Chu Shi had been attending a party hosted by Duke Chu, when he got onto a sitting mat without taking his socks off. This offended the Duke so much that he proposed Chu Shi should have his feet cut off. [ZUO Ai 25] Chu Shi is expelled. We learn no more about him after this episode, but one of his co-conspirators had his tomb dug up and his body burnt when Duke Chu returned to power after a few years.

Fàn Wénzĭ 范文子 (d. 574), also known as Shì Xiè 士燮, was the son of Shi Hui 士會, a dignitary in the state of Jin 晉. ZUO Cheng 2 praises him for insisting on a late return from a victorious battle against the state of Qi in 589 on the grounds that if he had returned early the honour for the victory would all have been his and not the army’s. His typical role in the old sources is throughout that of a wise adviser. In 575 he is said to have advised against an a military campaign by Jin against the state of Zheng 鄭. [SY 5.17] [ZUO Cheng 2 to Cheng 16 passim; SJ 39] [Fang Zhaohui 2002: 311-318]

Gōngsūn Níng 公孫寧 (fl. until 598), also known as Kŏng Nìng 孔寧, was a senior officer in the state of Chen 陳. He is said to have misled Duke Ling of Chen 陳靈公 (r. 613-599) into pursuing confused policies in the government of his state. But he is also mentioned as a successful general. CQ Xuan 11 records that the state of Lu 魯 returned him to his native Chen. [ZUO Wen 17, Xuan 11, Cheng 2]

seg.line: 公子結媵陳人之婦于鄄，

tls:text.tls:srcline: 公子結媵陳人之婦于鄄，

sense.def: Gōngzĭ Jié 公子結 (late 6th century), also known as Zĭqī 子期 was an elder brother of King Zhao of Chu 楚昭王 (r. 515 - 489). He served as minister of war under King Píng of Chŭ 楚平王 (r. 528-516). He is mentioned for an attack on Chen 陳 which he led as a general as late as in 485. [ZUO Ai 10; GONGYANG Ai 10]. [ZUO Zhuang 19, Ding 14, Ai 6; SJ 40]

Prince Zhí 公子職 (7th century) was the second eldest son of King Cheng of Chu 楚成王 (r. 671 - 626). Prince Zhí of Chŭ 楚公子職 was crown prince >Shāng Chén's 商臣 younger brother by a different mother. When King Chéng threatened to demote his son and designated successor Shāng Chén 商臣 in favour of Prince Zhi, Shang Chen managed to forced his own father to commit suicide and established he himself as King Mù of Chŭ 楚穆王 (r. 625 - 614). [ZUO Huan 16.5; LNZ 5]

Gŭsŏu 瞽瞍 (or 瞽叟) (legendary) was said to be the father of >Emperor Shun 舜. [Meng 6A6] Gusou became Master of Music specialising in the many-stringed se 瑟 instrument under >Emperor Yao defining the number of strings used on that instrument. He was satisfied with his son’s filial conduct. [MENG 4A28] He ceased to behave as his subject when he had become emperor. [MENG 5A4] If Gusou had committed a murder, Shun would have apprehended him for the crime. [MENG 7A35] It is said that Shun preferred a second son by a second wife to Gusou and repeatedly tried to kill Gusou. SY 6.7 has Confucius comment on the relation between Gusou and his father. [LSCQ 5.5; HSWZ 8.29, ed Xu Weiyu p. 300, SJ 1]
be worried about oneself, be concerned about oneself

tls:text.tls:line: What I obtain is much,

sense.def: e.g. 所樂 "what (the understood/contextually determinate subject) enjoys": the object Vt-ed by the the understood subject; that which (the understood subject) Vt-s

tls:text.tls:line: lo! it was the person he had seen in his dream.

sense.def: be the object of Vt-ing by the explicit or implicit subject in the context

tls:text.tls:line: is where King Wén (of Zhōu) escaped the thunderstorm.

sense.def: the place where the explicit or implicit subject of the phrase Vt-s the object N

tls:text.tls:line: "It is the Ts'oo prisoner, whom the people of Ch'ing delivered to us."

sense.def: the npro object which the understood or explicit subject has Vt-ed: 所亡地

tls:text.tls:line: are all designed for the right adjustment of the people.

sense.def: the means by which the explicit or implicit subject of V V-s: that by means of which

tls:text.tls:line: "The things which set a man up

sense.def: the means or method by which the explicit or implicit subject of V V-s: that by means of which

tls:text.tls:line: This is the source from which comes victory in battle.

sense.def: the objective source and cause for there being V-ing

tls:text.tls:line: by which one depraves himself;

sense.def: the objective cause from which the V-ing results

tls:text.tls:line: and it was of her that the people of Wèi made the song of "the Great Lady".

sense.def: those Vt-ing which/whom the explicit or implicit subject V-ed or V-s

tls:text.tls:line: 'Words are to give adequate expression to one's ideas;

sense.def: e.g. 以美其身 "is in order to beautify his person": be in order to, be designed to; serve the purpose of

tls:text.tls:line: nor die with him in his death,

sense.def: die for the contextually determinate object

tls:text.tls:line: I offer it as my means of asking (an escpape from) death." [ask to commit suicide (as punishment for leaving my village) if the jade turns out not to be genuine. CH]

sense.def: commit suicide

tls:text.tls:line: "The ruler of a State should not act lightly.

sense.def: should

tls:text.tls:line: "I promised to the late ruler.

sense.def: promise, public commitment

tls:text.tls:line: "I promised to the late ruler.

sense.def: make a promise, make a public commitment

tls:text.tls:line: "Yu-tsze Ch'ih (the elder brother of Keeh) ought indeed to succeed to his father,

sense.def: be a fact, be true enough

tls:text.tls:line: That's the way it is-

sense.def: be a fact, be true enough

tls:text.tls:line: That's the way it is-

sense.def: be definitely a fact; be definitely so

tls:text.tls:line: "Though it should five times attack us,

sense.def: our territory; our state; my state

tls:text.tls:line: "Then," said Kea, "we had better revolt from it at once.

sense.def: revolt against (also with places as (quasi-)subject)

seg.line: 其君無日不討國人而訓之于民生之不易、

tls:text.tls:srcline: 其君無日不討國人而訓之于民生之不易、
tls:text.tls:line: there is not a day when their ruler ruler does not train his leading personel and instruct them,when it comes to the common people it is not easy to ensure their survival,

sense.def: teach and train (a population for war, or officials for a task)

tls:text.tls:srcline: 其君無日不討國人而訓之于民生之不易、
tls:text.tls:line: there is not a day when their ruler ruler does not train his leading personel and instruct them,when it comes to the common people it is not easy to ensure their survival,

sense.def: instruct N2 about N1

tls:text.tls:line: One must be wary and fearful of them, and one cannot slacken in one's efforts.

sense.def: beware (something)

tls:text.tls:line: One must be wary and fearful of them, and one cannot slacken in one's efforts.

sense.def: be afraid (of) and be on one's guard against, be fearful and apprehensive about

tls:text.tls:line: One must be wary and fearful of them, and one cannot slacken in one's efforts.

sense.def: be full of wariness and fear of

tls:text.tls:line: One must be wary and fearful of them, and one cannot slacken in one's efforts.

sense.def: should

tls:text.tls:line: One must be wary and fearful of them, and one cannot slacken in one's efforts.

sense.def: e.g. 不可以 "should not": should

tls:text.tls:line: One must be wary and fearful of them, and one cannot slacken in one's efforts.

sense.def: slacken in one's efforts; be remiss; be lazy in performance of one's duty; be listless in performance

tls:text.tls:line: Disaster may strike them in no time.

sense.def: in no time

tls:text.tls:line: levied a tax on the lands of the State, to supply the (expenses of) marryingone of the duke's dauthers;

sense.def: impose taxes on

tls:text.tls:line: The people sang these lines on the occasion:

sense.def: compose a song about, (which runs as follows)

tls:text.tls:line: is it possible he should not be overthrown?"

sense.def: be defeated; fall into ruin

tls:text.tls:line: Shí Què remonstrated with the duke, saying,

sense.def: remonstrate with a contextually determinate person N or on a contextually determinate subject N (and say:)

tls:text.tls:line: "I swear by the sun,

sense.def: you

tls:text.tls:line: and the small States cherished his virtue,'

sense.def: show deep concern for; hold in one's heart, hold in one's mind; think fondly of, cherish in thought and action; take to heart

tls:text.tls:line: Now Jīng is not in accordance with these measures

sense.def: be appropriate, conform to standards of behaviour

tls:text.tls:line: He makes friends of the rich, and not of men of virtue-

sense.def: the rich, the wealthy

tls:text.tls:line: He makes friends of the rich, and not of men of virtue-

sense.def: the kind-hearted

tls:text.tls:line: He makes friends of the rich, and not of men of virtue-

sense.def: kind-hearted persons

tls:text.tls:line: the man had clandestine relations with Lady Po.

sense.def: have sexual relations with

tls:text.tls:line: She was beautiful but childless,

sense.def: enticing, (sexually) attractive (of lovers or temptresses) (often used as standard epithet

tls:text.tls:line: "How handsome and beautiful!"

sense.def: enticing, (sexually) attractive (of lovers or temptresses) (often used as standard epithet

tls:text.tls:line: and the people received their buff-coats, they all said,

sense.def: (an N) which (V-s) 葉實可啄食者 SW: 凡物無乳者

tls:text.tls:line: Without my having any idea of it, your lordship has come to my country.

sense.def: to my surprise, to one's surprise

tls:text.tls:line: "The use of precious articles is to preserve the people.

sense.def: safeguard, keep secure; keep to oneself; protect properly; HF 5.2.20: keep (one purposes) secure and secret

tls:text.tls:line: When duke Huì succeeded to the throne,

sense.def: ascend the throne

tls:text.tls:line: and they installed (Yí Wú, posthumously known as) Duke Hui (as ruler of Jìn).

sense.def: install as ruler from outside the capital, install a minister

tls:text.tls:line: the viscount of Chǔ sent Qū Wán to the army of the allies,

sense.def: the army of the contextually determinate N; army; OBI: military camp, encampment. Troops, armed force, division of the armed forces, regular armed forces; (obsolescent after Qin) HF 1.2: (several hundred thousand) organised armed personnel (should probably be npost-N)

tls:text.tls:line: to be greedy

sense.def: show greed for

tls:text.tls:line: They do not shrink from raising taxes for military maintenance

sense.def: keeping weapons in good repair

tls:text.tls:line: "The gentlemen, on the other hand, love their ruler,

sense.def: be well-disposed towards support emotionally; have loving feelings towards and take loving care of (superiors)

tls:text.tls:line: his minister of War remonstrated strongly with him, saying,

sense.def: remonstrate with a contextually determinate person N or on a contextually determinate subject N (and say:)

tls:text.tls:line: before those of Chǔ had all crossed the river;

sense.def: completely, altogether; all of the objects

tls:text.tls:line: before those of Chǔ had all crossed the river;

sense.def: cross over a contextually determinate place; cut across

tls:text.tls:line: (Zǐyù's son) Dà Xīn and Zǐxī enlisted (the Chǔ minister) Róng Huáng to remonstrate (with Zǐyù),

sense.def: remonstrate to the contextually determinate person

tls:text.tls:line: Zǐyù of Chǔ had made precious-jade-ornamented caps and jade-studded hatstrings,

sense.def: made of jade
bestow the honorary appellation N2 on the person N1 諡之曰

tls:text.tls:line: is our old friend.

sense.def: good diplomatic relations; acts of friendship

tls:text.tls:line: In calling the loved son to the State, we act a filial part.

sense.def: a person well liked

tls:text.tls:line: In calling the loved son to the State, we act a filial part.

sense.def: instate, establish formally in a position (as ruler or official)

tls:text.tls:line: In calling the loved son to the State, we act a filial part.

sense.def: beloved, 立愛 "establish the beloved (as a ruler)"

tls:text.tls:line: relieving one another's wants, congratulating in prosperity, condoling in calamity,

sense.def: offer condolences to

tls:text.tls:line: Tzu-p'i wished to place Yin Ho in charge of a city.

sense.def: govern; run the government of (a state)

tls:text.tls:line: Tzu-p'i wished to place Yin Ho in charge of a city.

sense.def: Standard Name: Hǎn Hǔ 罕虎 (Floruit ca. 559 B.C.)Alternative Name: Xuān Hǔ 軒虎 Personal Name: Zǐ Pí 子皮 Unger no. 159

tls:text.tls:line: You don't know if he can do the job or not."

sense.def: be not quite sure that Snom

tls:text.tls:line: "He is honest.

sense.def: be attentive and make an honest effort, sincere and diligent SW: 謹也

tls:text.tls:line: Then he will know better how to govern."

sense.def: govern others; conduct government

tls:text.tls:line: and employing him to cut things up.

sense.def: cut; scrape; cut up things

tls:text.tls:line: why should you be disowned?

sense.def: why? (i.e. surely for no good subjective reason)

tls:text.tls:line: why should you be disowned?

sense.def: why? (i.e. for no good objective reason)

tls:text.tls:line: 'Our amiable, courteous prince

sense.def: brotherly, affectionate-to-brothers
